At the last meeting of the Society I adventured to propose some 
arguments that seemed to me to evince the infinity 
of the Sphere of fixt Starrs: as occupying the whole 
Abysse of Space or the [Greek to pan] which at present is 
generally understood to be necessarily infinite and thence 
I laid be four you what may seem a very <u>Metaphysicall 
paradox <\u>, viz. that the number of Fixt Starrs must then
be more than any finite number, and some of them more 
than at a finite distance from others. This seemed lo in 
value a contradiction, but it is not the only one 
that occurrs to show who have undertaken freely to consider the 
nature of Infinite, which perhaps the very narrow limits 
of human capacity cannot attain to. Since then I have 
attentively examind what might be the consequence of an 
Hypothesis that the Sunn being one of the fixt Starrs, all
the rest were as far distant from one another as they 
are from us: and by a due calculation I find that there 
cannot, upon that supposition, be more than 13 points 
in the surface of a Sphere as far distant from the center of <s>a sphere <\s> it as they 
are from one another, and I believe it would be hard 
to find how to place thirteen Globes of equall mag 
nitude, so as to touch <s>ing<\s> one in the Center: for the....
angles of the <u>Icosaedron  <\u> are from one another very 
little more distant from its center that is, the side of the Trianglar 
Base of that Solid, is very little more than the semidiameter 
of the circumscribed sphere, it being to it nearly as 21 to 20.
So that it is plain that somewhat more than 12 equall spheres may 
be posited about a middle one; but the <s>Solid <\s> Sphericall angles or angles of the planes of 
these figures being incommensurable with the 360 gr 
of the Circle, there will be severall interstices lost, 
between some of the.... , but not such so as to receive in any 
part the thirteenth sphere: Hence it is no way im
